Modern Physics Letters A
Vol. 30, No. 1 (2015) 1550005 (13 pages)
c
World Scientific Publishing Company
DOI: 10.1142/S0217732315500054
Analysis on modified Chaplygin gas as dark energy model
Ya-Bo Wu * , Cheng-Yuan Zhang, Jian-Bo Lu, Jun-Wang Lu, Xue Zhang,
Qing-Mei Qi and Bi Fan
Department of Physics, Liaoning Normal University, Dalian 116029, P. R. China
* ybwu61@163.com
Received 26 September 2014
Revised 4 November 2014
Accepted 4 November 2014
Published 2 January 2015
In this paper, we will continue to study the modified Chaplygin gas (MCG) based on
Ref. 25. Concretely, we not only discuss both the change rates of the energy densities and
the Hubble parameter H(z) as a function of the model parameters, which is compared
and consistent with the related data in Ref. 27, but also perform the Om diagnostic
in order to geometrically differentiate the MCG model from the ΛCDM, GCG and CG
models. Moreover, we plot the evolutionary trajectories of MCG model with different
interaction terms in Om planes, and find that the coupling intensity b 2 plays an impor-
tant role in the MCG model. Furthermore, we also reconstruct the potential of MCG
scalar field as well as the dynamics of the scalar field according to the evolution of the
MCG dark energy. It is worth stressing that the results given by us can include the ones
without interaction as the special cases.
Keywords: Modified Chaplygin gas; dark energy; Om diagnostic.
PACS Nos.: 98.80.-k, 98.80.Jk
text.body:
1. Introduction
More recently, new evidence from astrophysics and cosmology has revealed a quite
unexpected picture of the universe. Precisely, the latest datasets such as type Ia
Supernovae and Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB)
1–5 radiation strongly show
an accelerated expansion of the Universe. And the observations indicate that the
energy budget of the universe is as follows: ordinary baryonic matter is 4%, the
contribution of dark matter (DM) is 26%, and the dark energy (DE) with positive
energy density and negative pressure occupies about 70% of the total energy of the
universe, which is responsible for the accelerated expansion of universe.
Over the past decade there have been many theoretical models for mimicking
the dark energy, such as the simplest cosmological constant model, i.e. the ΛCDM
text.note:
Mod. Phys. Lett. A 2015.30. Downloaded from www.worldscientific.com
by EUROPEAN ORGANIZATION FOR NUCLEAR RESEARCH (CERN) on 04/13/15. For personal use only.
December 30, 2014 16:10
MPLA
S0217732315500054 page 2
Y.-B. Wu et al.
text.body:
model, in which the equation of state (EoS) is independent of the cosmic time, and
it can fit the observations well. However, two problems arise from this scenario,
namely the " fine-tuning " and " the cosmic coincidence " problems. In order to solve
these two problems, many dynamical dark energy models were proposed, whose
EoS evolves with cosmic time. The scalar field or quintessence
6–8 is one of the most
favored candidates of dark energy, which produces sufficient negative pressure to
drive acceleration. In order to alleviate the cosmological-constant problems and
explain the acceleration expansion, many dynamical dark energy models were con-
structed, such as Phantom,
9,10 Quintom,
11 Tachyon,
12 K-essence,
13 Chaplygin gas
model
14,15 etc. Meanwhile, some other interacting dark energy models including the
modified Chaplygin gas model,
16 braneworld model
17 and holographic dark energy
model
18 were also established. Recently, based on the principle of quantum gravity,
the agegraphic dark energy
19 model has been put forward and further extended to
new agegraphic dark energy
20 model.
As we know, the Chaplygin gas model can be used to unify the dark energy and
dark matter by allowing an EoS evolving with time. And the generalized Chaplygin
gas (GCG) model,
21 described by the EoS p GCG = −
B
ρ α
GCG
(0 < α ≤ 1), behaves as
dust-like matter at early times and a cosmological constant at late stages. Moreover,
the GCG model can be extended to the modified Chaplygin gas (MCG) model,
22,23
which interpolates between standard fluid at high energy density and Chaplygin
gas fluid at low energy density. The EoS for the MCG model is p = Aρ −
B
ρ α .
Based on Ref. 25, in this paper we will continue to study the MCG model by
discussing the density gradient for dark matter and dark energy as well as the
Hubble parameter H(z) as a function of the model parameters in Sec. 2. The Om
diagnostic to differentiate the MCG model from the ΛCDM, GCG and CG models
is preformed in Sec. 3. Specifically, we plot the evolutionary trajectories of the MCG
model with different interaction terms in Om planes, and find that the coupling
intensity b
2 , which is a constant denoting the transfer strength, plays an important
role in the MCG model. In Sec. 4, we reconstruct the potential of the MCG scalar
field as well as the dynamics of the scalar field according to the evolution of the
MCG dark energy, and the results given by us can reduce to the cases without
interaction.
2. The Evolutions of Change Rates of the Dark Energy Densities
We consider a cosmological model with two components: the MCG and the baryon
fluid, i.e. the total energy density ρ t = ρ MCG + ρ b . As a unified model of two dark
sectors, we assume that the MCG fluid is made up of two components, namely DE
and DM, i.e.
ρ MCG = ρ de + ρ dm ,
(1)
p MCG = p de .
(2)

reduced to the CG scenario.

Fig. 1. The factor S and P vs. the redshift z, where As = 0.74, α = 0.5, A = 0.012.
From Eq. (7), it is easy to see that the sign of the value of
dρ de
dz depends on the
factor S. Figure 1(a) shows not only the relation between factor S and the redshift z,
but also the evolutionary behavior of the change rate of the energy density from
the past to the future, from which we see that as the redshift z decreases,
dρ de
dz
gradually increases to −0.08 at z = 1.95 and then decreases to −0.14 at z = 0.35,
after that it increases rapidly, and eventually tends to be relatively stable. When
z = −0.70, it approaches 0. The factor S is always less than zero in contrast with
the value of P , which means that with the decrease of the redshift z, the energy
density of DE increases all the time although its change rate is different. That is to
say, there is an energy transfer from DM to DE, which is in good agreement with
the one in Fig. 1(b).
Specially, for the case without interaction between DE and DM, by means of

In the following analysis, the Gaussian H 0 prior H 0 + σ H0 = 68 ±
2.8 km s
−1 Mpc
−1 is used, which comes from the median statistics analysis of
553 H 0 measurements
28 and is consistent with the earlier estimates of Gott et al.
29
and Chen et al.
30 Thus, for the MCG model, the four H(z) data points can be
obtained, i.e. H(z) = 72.2 ± 2.97 km s
−1 Mpc
−1 at z = 0.07, H(z) = 74.53 ±
3.06 km s
−1 Mpc
−1 at z = 0.1, H(z) = 76.34 ± 3.16 km s
−1 Mpc
−1 at z = 0.12
and H(z) = 385.45 ± 15.87 km s
−1 Mpc
−1 at z = 1, which can be compared with
the data determined by using a number of different techniques as in Ref. 27. Our
results show that the first three values of H(z) in the MCG model are compatible
with those listed in Ref. 27.
3. Om Diagnostic
It is well known that Om diagnostic
31 is constructed based on the Hubble parameter
H, which can geometrically differentiate the ΛCDM model from the CG, GCG and
MCG models. The Om diagnostic is defined as

Thus, according to Eq. (21), by taking Ω 0de = 0.7, Ω 0dm = 0.25, Ω 0b = 0.05,
we can obtain the Om parameters of the MCG model corresponding to the above
different interaction terms, which are plotted in Fig. 3.
Figure 3(a) shows that for a fixed interaction term Γ = 3b
2 Hρ MCG , different
coupling intensity b
2 corresponds to the different evolutionary trajectories. More-
over, the constant b
2 has greater influence on the trajectories in the past (near
z > 0) than those in the present. What is more, the larger the value of b
2 , the
more obvious the curves change. Ultimately, these curves approach to the ΛCDM
fixed point as z = 0, which implies that the model behaves as a ΛCDM model in
the future, and our universe will enter a de Sitter phase. Figure 3(b) indicates that
the evolutionary trends of the three curves are not only roughly the same, even
though with the different values of b
2 , but also all nearly parallel to the one in the
ΛCDM model. In Fig. 3(c), with the interaction term Γ = 3b
2 Hρ dm , a crossing
point arises at z = 2.4. However, all of the Om curves go from decreasing to in-
creasing gradually as the redshift z decreases, and their behaviors are completely
different from each other when 0 < z < 2.0. Based on the above three cases, it
follows that the constant b
2 plays a very important role in the evolution of the
MCG model. Especially, when taking b
2 = 0, expression (21) can be reduced to
the situation in the absence of interaction. Figure 3(d) illustrates the evolutions of
Om parameter corresponding to the three different interaction terms in the case of
b
2 = 0.14. Taking Γ = 3b
2 Hρ de and Γ = 3b
2 Hρ dm , both the corresponding evolu-
tionary trends of Om parameters are basically the same. However, when we take
Γ = 3b
2 Hρ MCG , the trajectory of curve deviates obviously from the ΛCDM model
as the redshift z increases. Furthermore, by using Om diagnostic approach, we can
also distinguish the MCG model from the other models clearly, and find that there
are great differences among them. Especially, in Fig. 3(e), the three curves represent
CG, GCG and MCG models with interaction are quite different from the ΛCDM
model when 0 < z < 1.9. To the contrary, they coincide together as z = 0 and
z > 1.9.

Fig. 4. Om evolution diagram versus the redshift (z) for the CG (dotted), GCG (dot-dashed),
MCG (dashed) and ΛCDM (solid) models, where Ω 0dm = 0.25, Ω 0de = 0.7, Ω 0b = 0.05 and
As = 0.74.
For the convenience of comparison, we plot the evolutionary trajectories of CG,
GCG models as well as ΛCDM model represented by the horizontal solid line in
Fig. 4, from which we find that the evolutionary trend of MCG model is analogous
to that of GCG model, but appears slightly different in the early period. When
z > 2, the evolutionary trajectory of the CG model is almost the same as the
GCG model, though corresponding to different values of Om. Furthermore, these
trajectories have an identical crossing point with horizontal solid line at present. It
follows that when taking different values of A and α, Eq. (28) can reduce to the
Om of CG, GCG and ΛCDM models.
4. Reconstruction of the MCG Scalar Field of Dark Energy with
Interaction
At present it is believed that the current accelerated expansion is driven by a
dynamical scalar field φ with potential V (φ), related to the energy density and the
pressure of dark energy
32–34 as
ρ φ =
1
2
˙
φ
2 + V (φ) ,
(29)
p φ =
1
2
˙
φ
2
− V (φ) .
(30)
Hence, we have
˙
φ
2 = ρ φ + p φ ,
(31)
V (φ) =
ρ φ − p φ
2
.
(32)
We will reconstruct the potential and the dynamics. To do this, we treat the MCG
as an ordinary scalar field φ. By means of ρ φ = ρ de(MCG) and p φ = p de , according
to Eqs. (3)–(5), the kinetic term can be rewritten as

Fig. 5. The reconstruction of the potential V for the interacting MCG with different coupling
intensity b 2 in the case of the fixed interaction terms Γ = 3b 2 Hρ de (a), 3b 2 Hρ dm (b) and
3b 2 Hρ MCG (c).
In particular, for b
2 = 0, one gets
V 1 = V 2 = V 3 = V (φ) =
1 − ω de
2(1 + ω de )
(φ
H)
2 .
(42)
In Fig. 5, we plot the reconstruction of the potential V concretely. Figure 5(a)
illustrates that the potential V increases with the increasing φ. However, by com-
paring Fig. 5(a) with (b) and (c), we find that there are many differences among
them, such as that the trends of (b) and (c) are diametrically opposed to (a) except
for the case of b
2 = 0, and that V decreases sharply and then increases gradually
as φ increases, i.e. the weaker the interaction, the faster the potential V changes.
In addition, the evolutions of the scalar field φ(a) are also displayed in Fig. 6, from
which we see that φ(a) goes up as the scalar factor increases for the fixed value
of b
2 . Moreover, with the evolution of the scale factor to today, the effects of the
interaction terms on the evolution of φ(a) are basically the same, and tend to an
identical value at a = 1. From Figs. 6(a) and (c), we also see that the evolutionary
curves corresponding to different interaction terms overlap, which means that the
values of b
2 nearly have no effect on the evolutionary trajectories of φ(a). However,
Fig. 6(b) illustrates the faint effects of b
2 on φ(a).

Fig. 6. The evolutions of the scalar field φ(a) for interacting MCG with different coupling inten-
sity b 2 , corresponds to Γ = 3b 2 Hρ de (a), 3b 2 Hρ dm (b) and 3b 2 Hρ MCG (c), respectively.
5. Conclusions
In summary, for the modified Chaplygin gas (MCG) model with interaction we have
discussed both the change rates of the energy densities and the Hubble parameter
H(z) as a function of the model parameters, which is compared and consistent
with the related data in Ref. 27. Moreover, we have performed the Om diagnostic
in order to geometrically differentiate the MCG model from ΛCDM, GCG and CG
models. Concretely, we plotted the evolutionary trajectories of the MCG model
with different interaction terms in Om planes. Furthermore, we have shown that
the coupling intensity b
2 plays an important role in the MCG model. Also, we have
reconstructed the potential of the MCG scalar field as well as the dynamics of the
scalar field according to the evolution of the MCG dark energy. Different values
of b
2 correspond to different evolutions of the potential V , and the stronger the
interaction, the slower the potential V changes with increasing φ. In particular, it
is worth mentioning that the results given by us can reduce to the cases without
interaction.
